title: How to make your writing suspenseful - Victoria Smith

multiple-choice.question: What, according to H.P. Lovecraft, is the oldest and strongest kind of fear?
Which literary device sets up a question that the audience hopes to get an answer to and delays that answer while maintaining their interest and keeping them guessing?
What is one technique to achieve suspense in writing, according to the transcript?
How does the use of nighttime, fog, and storms contribute to suspense in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: By creating a sense of clarity and visibility

options.label: B
options.text: By limiting visibility and restricting characters' movements

options.label: C
options.text: By making the setting more beautiful

options.label: D
options.text: By making the characters more confident

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how Edgar Allan Poe conveys the mental state of the narrator in "The Tell-Tale Heart"?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the use of long, descriptive sentences

options.label: B
options.text: Through the use of fragmented sentences that break off suddenly

options.label: C
options.text: Through the use of poetic language

multiple-choice.question: What is dramatic irony, and how is it used in suspenseful storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: Dramatic irony is when the audience knows more than the characters, and it is used to create suspense by revealing key parts of the big secret to the audience but not to the characters.

options.label: B
options.text: Dramatic irony is when the characters know more than the audience, and it is used to create suspense by keeping the audience in the dark.

options.label: C
options.text: Dramatic irony is when the audience and characters know the same amount of information, and it is used to create suspense by revealing the plot twist early.

options.label: D
options.text: Dramatic irony is when the author knows more than the audience and characters, and it is used to create suspense by using foreshadowing.

multiple-choice.question: What is a cliffhanger, and how is it used in suspenseful storytelling?

options.label: A
options.text: A cliffhanger is when a chapter or episode ends with a sense of closure and emotional release, and it is used to create suspense by giving the audience a sense of satisfaction.

options.label: B
options.text: A cliffhanger is when a chapter or episode ends right before something crucial is revealed, or in the midst of a dangerous situation with a slim chance of hope, and it is used to create suspense by making the audience wonder what will happen next.

options.label: C
options.text: A cliffhanger is when a chapter or episode ends with a plot twist, and it is used to create suspense by surprising the audience.

options.label: D
options.text: A cliffhanger is when a chapter or episode ends with a resolution, and it is used to create suspense by tying up loose ends.

multiple-choice.question: How does the use of setting and imagery contribute to suspense in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: By creating a sense of comfort and familiarity

options.label: B
options.text: By suggesting that disturbing things are being concealed

options.label: C
options.text: By making the setting more beautiful

options.label: D
options.text: By making the characters more confident

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how Alfred Hitchcock's cinematography creates suspense?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the use of bright colors and upbeat music

options.label: B
options.text: Through the use of extended silences and shots of staircases

options.label: C
options.text: Through the use of fast-paced editing and quick cuts

options.label: D
options.text: Through the use of long takes and static shots

multiple-choice.question: Why is suspense important in storytelling, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it creates a sense of closure and emotional release

options.label: B
options.text: Because it makes the audience wonder what will happen next

options.label: C
options.text: Because it creates a sense of comfort and familiarity

options.label: D
options.text: Because it ties up loose ends

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Each chapter is written in a different language

options.label: C
options.text: Each chapter is written in a different style

options.label: D
options.text: Each chapter is written by a different author

options.label: B
options.text: Due to its explicit content and sexual references

options.label: C
options.text: Due to its depiction of Dublin

options.label: D
options.text: Due to its criticism of the government

options.label: A
options.text: It is written in a more traditional style

options.label: B
options.text: It is written in a stream-of-consciousness style with almost no punctuation

options.label: C
options.text: It is written in a poetic style

options.label: D
options.text: It is written in a dialogue-driven style

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the city that is vividly depicted in "Ulysses"?
Why did James Joyce claim that if Dublin were to be destroyed, it could be recreated from the pages of "Ulysses"?

options.label: B
options.text: Because he loved the city and took great care in precisely representing its details

options.label: C
options.text: Because he wanted to show off his writing skills

options.label: D
options.text: Because he wanted to confuse his readers

options.label: A
options.text: He apologized for the book's complexity

options.label: B
options.text: He said that if "Ulysses" isn't worth reading, then life isn't worth living

title: What in the world is topological quantum matter? - Fan Zhang

multiple-choice.question: What is the main focus of the branch of mathematics known as topology?

options.label: A
options.text: Studying the behavior of subatomic particles

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding the fundamental properties of objects that remain unchanged when stretched or bent

options.label: C
options.text: Analyzing the behavior of electricity in different materials

options.label: D
options.text: Examining the properties of quantum computers

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following objects would be considered the same by a topologist?

options.label: B
options.text: A coffee cup and a plate

options.label: C
options.text: A donut and a coffee cup

multiple-choice.question: What was the significant discovery made by David Thouless, Duncan Haldane, and Michael Kosterlitz?

options.label: A
options.text: That topology is only applicable to macroscopic objects

options.label: B
options.text: That subatomic particles do not exhibit topological properties

options.label: C
options.text: That topological properties exist at the quantum level

options.label: D
options.text: That quantum computers are not feasible

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of a topological insulator?

options.label: A
options.text: It conducts electricity throughout the material

options.label: B
options.text: It conducts electricity only at the edge of the material

options.label: C
options.text: It does not conduct electricity at all

options.label: D
options.text: It only conducts electricity in the presence of a strong magnetic field

multiple-choice.question: How do the topological properties of a material affect its conductivity?

options.label: A
options.text: They make it more susceptible to impurities and imperfections

options.label: B
options.text: They have no impact on conductivity

options.label: C
options.text: They make it less susceptible to impurities and imperfections

options.label: D
options.text: They only affect conductivity at high temperatures

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of topological insulators in electronics?

options.label: C
options.text: Improving the accuracy of classical digital computers

options.label: D
options.text: Enhancing the conductivity of copper wires

multiple-choice.question: What is a qubit in the context of quantum computing?

options.label: A
options.text: A unit of measurement for the speed of a quantum computer

options.label: B
options.text: A type of quantum particle that can exist in multiple states at once

options.label: C
options.text: A way of storing information in a quantum computer

options.label: D
options.text: A method for cooling quantum computers

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential benefit of using topological qubits in quantum computing?

options.label: A
options.text: They would be more prone to errors due to environmental interactions

options.label: B
options.text: They would be less stable than classical qubits

options.label: C
options.text: They would be more stable and less susceptible to environmental interactions

options.label: D
options.text: They would only be useful for solving classical problems

multiple-choice.question: What was the original focus of topology as a branch of mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding the behavior of subatomic particles

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential outcome of applying topological principles to the development of quantum computers?

options.label: A
options.text: They would become less accurate and more prone to errors

options.label: B
options.text: They would become more accurate and efficient

options.label: C
options.text: They would only be useful for solving classical problems

options.label: D
options.text: They would require more power to operate

title: Why should you read Virgil's "Aeneid"? - Mark Robinson

multiple-choice.question: In what year did the Roman poet Virgil die?

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall theme of the Aeneid?

options.label: C

title: Why is it so hard to cure cancer? - Kyuson Yun

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate number of people affected by cancer at any given time?
How many different types of cancer are there?
What happens to normal cells when they accumulate mutations?

options.label: B
options.text: They can detect and fix mutations or self-destruct

options.label: C
options.text: They become immune to further mutations

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of multiple types of cancer in a single patient

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The ability of cancer cells to adapt to changing environments

options.text: The formation of blood vessels that feed a tumor

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because cancer cells are too aggressive

options.label: B
options.text: By suppressing the immune system's function

options.label: C
options.text: By allowing the immune system to recognize and destroy the cancer

options.label: D
options.text: By reducing the complexity of the tumor ecosystem

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are responsible for the formation of blood vessels that feed the tumor

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By becoming more aggressive and invasive

options.label: C
options.text: By forming new blood vessels to feed the tumor

options.label: D
options.text: By suppressing the immune system's function

multiple-choice.question: What is the implication of cancer cells being masters of adaptation for cancer treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: That treatments should be tailored to specific types of cancer

options.label: B
options.text: That treatments should be designed to target cancer stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: That treatments should be able to adjust as the cancer changes

options.label: D
options.text: That treatments are unlikely to be effective

options.label: B
options.text: The loss of knowledge and history

options.text: The loss of food and water

title: Why Facts Don't Convince People (and what you can do about it)

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary basis for human decision-making?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not educated enough

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain processes challenges to worldview as physical danger

options.text: Because they are not interested in learning

options.label: B
options.text: When people become more convinced of their original ideas after encountering contradictory facts

options.label: C
options.text: When people ignore new facts and continue with their original ideas

options.text: When people become aggressive when encountering new facts

options.text: Identifying common ground and shared identity

options.text: Because it models a willingness to learn and change

title: A Saudi woman who dared to drive - Manal al-Sharif

options.label: C

title: How many ways are there to prove the Pythagorean theorem? - Betty Fei

multiple-choice.question: What is the Pythagorean theorem, and what does it describe?

options.label: A
options.text: The theorem describes the relationship between the radius and circumference of a circle.

options.label: B
options.text: The theorem states that the square of one side plus the square of the other side is equal to the square of the hypotenuse in a right triangle.

options.label: C
options.text: The theorem describes the relationship between the area and perimeter of a rectangle.

options.label: D
options.text: The theorem states that the sum of the interior angles of a triangle is always 180 degrees.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Greek philosopher and mathematician who is credited with the discovery of the Pythagorean theorem?

options.label: A
options.text: The converse states that a triangle with sides of length 3, 4, and 5 must be a right triangle, and it was used to make square corners.

options.label: B
options.text: The converse states that a triangle with sides of length 3, 4, and 5 must be an equilateral triangle, and it was used to make circular foundations.

options.label: C
options.text: The converse states that a triangle with sides of length 3, 4, and 5 must be an isosceles triangle, and it was used to make triangular foundations.

options.label: D
options.text: The converse states that a triangle with sides of length 3, 4, and 5 must be a scalene triangle, and it was used to make rectangular foundations.

How many proofs of the Pythagorean theorem are mentioned in the transcript as existing?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the principle of conservation of energy

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate the principle of conservation of momentum

options.label: D
options.text: To demonstrate the principle of buoyancy

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the areas of the squares formed by the sides of a right triangle, according to the Pythagorean theorem?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The sum of the areas of the squares is equal to twice the area of the largest square.

options.label: C
options.text: The sum of the areas of the squares is equal to the difference between the areas of the largest and smallest squares.

options.label: D
options.text: The sum of the areas of the squares is equal to the product of the areas of the largest and smallest squares.

title: How you think about who you are matters more than ever - Chetan Bhatt

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main argument about identity and origin?

options.label: A
options.text: That people should be proud of their origins and identity.

options.label: B
options.text: That origin stories and identity myths make people feel secure.

options.label: C
options.text: That people should reject every origin myth that claims them and develop a deeper sense of personhood.

options.label: D
options.text: That identity is solely determined by one's cultural background.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's response to the question "Where are you from?"

options.label: B
options.text: He explains his complex background, including his grandparents' and parents' birthplaces.

options.label: C
options.text: He refuses to answer the question.

options.label: D
options.text: He says he is from India.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on tradition and history?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes that tradition and history are the same thing.

options.label: B
options.text: He believes that tradition is more important than history.

options.label: C
options.text: He believes that tradition and history are often in conflict.

options.label: D
options.text: He believes that tradition is irrelevant in modern times.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example given by the speaker of a person who changed their identity?

options.label: A
options.text: A Hindu boy from Britain who became a Christian.

options.label: B
options.text: A Muslim boy from India who became a Hindu.

options.label: C
options.text: A Hindu boy from Britain who became an Al Qaeda fighter.

options.label: D
options.text: A Christian boy from America who became a Muslim.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the claim to tradition made by fundamentalist groups?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes that their claim to tradition is legitimate.

options.label: B
options.text: He believes that their claim to tradition is at war with history.

options.label: C
options.text: He believes that their claim to tradition is irrelevant.

options.label: D
options.text: He believes that their claim to tradition is a personal choice.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the concept of purity in identity?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes that purity is essential to one's identity.

options.label: B
options.text: He believes that purity is a myth that can lead to lethal visions of perfect societies.

options.label: C
options.text: He believes that purity is a personal choice.

options.label: D
options.text: He believes that purity is irrelevant in modern times.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the relationship between culture and identity?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes that culture determines one's identity.

options.label: B
options.text: He believes that culture is a part of one's identity, but not the only factor.

options.label: C
options.text: He believes that culture is irrelevant to one's identity.

options.label: D
options.text: He believes that culture is a fixed entity that cannot be changed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example given by the speaker of a person who challenged the dominant views of their time?

options.label: A
options.text: Ibn Rushd, a Muslim judge and thinker who advocated for secularism.

options.label: B
options.text: Mahatma Gandhi, an Indian independence activist who advocated for non-violence.

options.label: C
options.text: A Hindu fundamentalist leader who advocated for a return to traditional values.

options.label: D
options.text: A Muslim fundamentalist leader who advocated for a strict interpretation of Islamic law.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the concept of authenticity in identity?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes that authenticity is essential to one's identity.

options.label: B
options.text: He believes that authenticity is a myth that can lead to a fixed and narrow view of oneself.

options.label: C
options.text: He believes that authenticity is a personal choice.

options.label: D
options.text: He believes that authenticity is irrelevant in modern times.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To be proud of their origins and identity.

options.label: B
options.text: To reject every origin myth that claims them and develop a deeper sense of personhood.

options.label: C
options.text: To follow the teachings of their ancestors.

title: The science of smog - Kim Preshoff

multiple-choice.question: What was the name given to the thick gray haze that covered cities such as London, Glasgow, and Edinburgh at the beginning of the 20th century?

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.text: Only affects young children and older people
